choices.text: Disappearance of the Mullerian duct
Differentiation of the Wolffian duct
Differentiation of the gonad into the testes
Disappearance of the ovary

questions.text: Presence of the SRY gene will cause what important development in embryology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Differentiation of the gonad into the testes

 

Explanation:

 

Normal Sex Development

 

  • Sex development starts in utero and continues in adult life with attainment of sexual maturity and reproductive capability
  • Major determinants of sex development are
    • Chromosomal Sex (46XX or 46XY)
    • Gonadal sex (Testes or ovary)
    • Phenotypic sex (External genitalia)
  • Sex determination primarily begins by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome
  • On the Short arm of the Y chromosome, there is located the SRY gene (Sex Determining Region) – Yp11.3 and is the most important genetic aspect for sex determination and its presence or absence determines the direction of gonadal differentiation.
  • SRY activates several other genes that promote testis development. These include
    • SOX 9
    • Fgf 9
  • In 46 XX embryos, genes responsible include Wnt4 and Rspo 1.
  • The chromosomal sex determines the gonadal sex (i.e. whether the gonads will become testes or ovaries) in the embryo.
  • The gonads are BIPOTENT (Undifferentiated) till 5 weeks, they then differentiate into testes or ovaries based on whether the karyotype is 46XX or 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On the Short arm of the Y chromosome, there is located the SRY gene (Sex Determining Region) – Yp11.3 and is the most important genetic aspect for sex determination and its presence or absence determines the direction of gonadal differentiation.
  • SRY activates several other genes that promote testis development.

questions.text: A curious pregnant patient visits the antenatal OPD. She has missed her period by 4 days and her pregnancy test is positive. This is her 1st pregnancy and although, sex detection is banned in India, she is very curious about how the baby forms and asks if it is possible to know the sex of the baby now. You tell her that the gonads are undifferentiated at present. The gonads are bipotent till?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 5 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • The gonads are BIPOTENT (Undifferentiated) till 5 weeks, they then differentiate into testes or ovaries based on whether the karyotype is 46XX or 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 45 XO gonadal dysgenesis
46 XX gonadal dysgeneses
46 XY gonadal dysgenesis
46 XXY gonadal dysgenesis

questions.text: Swyer syndrome is an example of
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis

 

Explanation:

 

46 XY Complete gonadal dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

 

  • Uncommon form of gonadal dysgenesis; 46XY karyotype
  • The dysgenetic gonads don’t produce AMH/ Androgens, so Phenotype is female.
  • They have a normal uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix and vagina
  • No masculinization of external genitalia
  • 15% mutation of SRY gene
  • Majority: No cause identified
  • Present as
    • Primary amenorrhoea
    • Delayed sexual maturation
    • Normal pubic hair
    • Normal female internal and external genitalia
  • Diagnosis:
    • Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism
    • Karyotype
  • Treatment
  • Sex of assignment and rearing: Female
  • Gonadectomy soon after diagnosis
  • Estrogen: to maintain sexual maturation and breast development
  • Pregnancy can be achieved with IVF with donor oocytes

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: 45 XO gonadal dysgenesis: This is Turner syndrome
  • Option B: 46 XX gonadal dysgenesis: There is no particular name but it includes ovarian dysgenesis leading to hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Option D: 46 XXY gonadal dysgenesis: This is Klinefelter syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 46 XY complete gonadal dysgenesis is Swyer syndrome

choices.text: Increased testosterone/ DHT ratio
Decreased testosterone/ DHT ratio
No change in the testosterone/ DHT ratio
Absent testosterone levels

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is of normal height, at the top of her class but her mother is concerned because of a sudden increase in hair growth and hoarseness of voice. She also mentions that she hasn’t yet attained menarche. On examination, there is absent breast development and minimal presence of pubic and axillary hair. There is also increased facial hair growth and on local examination, there is an enlarged clitoris. An ultrasound reveals an absent uterus with the presence of gonad-like structures in the inguinal canal. Suspecting 5 alpha reductase deficiency, testosterone and DHT level is done. What is the expected finding in 5 alpha reductase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increased testosterone/ DHT ratio

 

Explanation:

 

5 α Reductase Deficiency

 

  • Autosomal recessive
  • Karyotype: 46XY
  • Defective conversion of Testosterone to DHT (which is mediated by the enzyme 5 alpha reductase)
  • Testosterone (in fetal life): causes development of the internal male genitalia
  • DHT is responsible for external male genital development: Hence this does not develop as the enzyme mediating the conversion is absent/ deficient
  • Classical presentation:
    • External genitalia: predominantly Female at birth
    • Internal genitalia: Male (The epididymis, the vas deferens, seminal vesicles and ejaculatory ducts form but empty into a short blind vagina)
    • Testis: Located in the inguinal canal
    • At Puberty: Virilization of varying degrees
    • Affected men develop a normal muscle mass, libido, deepening of voice (Testosterone dependent) but have less body hair, less temporal hairline recession, no acne (All these are DHT dependent)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Suspect in infants with genital ambiguity
    • Suspect in adolescence with the characteristic phenotype and a serum hormonal profile showing normal male level testosterone and an increased testosterone/ DHT ratio

choices.text: Review ultrasound after 1 year

questions.text: A 45-year old presents for a routine gynecological checkup. She is having regular cycles with normal flow and mild dysmenorrhea on the 1st day. She is a non-smoker and has no history of hypertension or diabetes. Her last pap smear was 2 years back which was reported to be normal. An ultrasound shows the presence of a 4 x 4 cm intramural fibroid with a sub-serosal component. She is very anxious and seeks your opinion on what should be done.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Review ultrasound after 1 year

Explanation:

  • This is an asymptomatic fibroid
  • Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation.
  • Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid

Other Options

  • Option A: GnRH agonists: This can be given to women with symptomatic fibroids to reduce the size and also control symptoms. It is also given to women pre-operatively to reduce the size of the fibroid
  • Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy: There is no indication for surgical managment in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. Following menopause, fibroids usually shrink in size due to hypo-estrogenism. 
  • Option C: Laparoscopic myomectomy: There is no indication for doing a myomectomy in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. 

Educational Objective:

Management of symotomatic fibroids can be medical or surgical or newer non invasive techniques 

1. Medical Management

  • Non Hormonal:
    • NSAIDs for pain and heavy bleeding
    • Anti-fibrinolytics (Tranexamic acid): For heavy bleeding
  • Hormonal
    • Combined OCPS
    • SPRMs
      • Ulipristal acetate
      • Mifepristone
    • LNG-IUS: in small fibroids NOT distorting the uterine cavity
    • GnRH agonists
    • GnRH antagonists

2. Surgical Management

a. Myomectomy (Laparoscopic/ Laparotomy/ Hysteroscopic for submucous myomas)

b. Hysterectomy: Preferred in women who are not wanting future fertility with large/ multiple symptomatic fibroids
 

3. Non invasive

a. Magnetic Resonance Guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS)

b. Uterine artery embolization

 

*Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation.

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

choices.text: Analgesia and hydration
Hysterotomy and myomectomy

questions.text: A 23-year primi is presents at 16 weeks pregnancy with acute abdominal pain. On examination, the uterus is 20 weeks size and there is tenderness over the abdomen. An ultrasound reveals, a 6 cm fibroid in the anterior wall. What is the next best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Analgesia and hydration

Explanation

  • This is most likely a red degeneration of fibroid which is commonly seen in pregnancy.
  • Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2nd half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • Pain is the predominant symptom.
  • Treatment is supportive and pain usually settles with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs

Other Options

  • Option A: Advise MTP: This is usually never advised in red degeneration as majority of red degenerations will symotomatically improve
  • Option B: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Not indicated during pregnancy
  • Option C: Hysterotomy and myomectomy: Nor indicated in red degeneration of fibroid

Educational Objective: 

  • Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2nd half of pregnancy and puerperium.
  • Pain is the predominant symptom.
  • Treatment is supportive and pain usually settles with analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs

Ref: Page no 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology

questions.text: The most common degeneration seen in uterine fibroids is
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyaline degeneration

Explanation

  • The most common type of degeneration in fibroids is hyaline degeneration

Red degeneration, calcific degeneration and fatty degeneration are other kinds of degeneration in fibroids 

Educational Objective:

  • The most common type of degeneration in fibroids is hyaline degeneration

Ref: Page no 227, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology

questions.text: A 34-year nulliparous woman presents to the OPD. She complains of pelvic heaviness. She also mentions that her periods have been increasingly heavy in amount and she has to take a pain killer on the 1st 2 days of her period due to excessive pain. The periods are otherwise regular. On examination, there is an irregular mass palpated abdominally which is about the size of an 18 weeks gravid uterus. On bimanual exam, the same irregular mass is felt and there is transmitted mobility. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Leiomyoma

Explanation

  • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp.
  • On examination, this is  a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids)
    • The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular
    • There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses)
    • The woman is nulliparous

Other Options:

  • In adenomyosis, the uterus is regularly enlarged (max size of 12-14 weeks size)
  • In fibroid polyp, the uterus will be normal or slightly enlarged in size and on speculum exam, a polyp may be seen extruding from the os. Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding
  • In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)

Educational Objective: 

C/f of fibroid uterus

Symptoms

  • Menorrhagia
  • Dysmenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Abdominal mass and pressure symptoms

Signs:

  • Uterus regularly enlarged (single fibroid) or irregularly enlarged (multiple fibroids)
  • Transmitted mobility is felt in a fibroid 

 

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 27-year woman who is anxious to conceive visits the OPD with her husband. They have been trying to conceive for 2 years. She has regular periods with heavy flow. There is associated dysmenorrhea. A transvaginal scan shows a submucosal fibroid of about 2 cm in size. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopic myomectomy

Explanation:

This patient is infertile and has a submucosal fibroid. The fibroid has to be removed. Type 0 and 1 submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically

Other Options

  • Option A: Laparoscopic myomectomy: Is indicated usually in intramural and subserosal fibroids
  • Option B: Reassurance: Whenever an infertile patient has a submucosal fibroid or a large intra-mural fibroid, it has to be removed.
  • Option C: GnRH agonist: Could have been tried if the patient did not have infertility. 

Educational Objective:

  • Indications of myomectomy in infertility are:
    • Submucous fibroids
    • Large intramural fibroids distorting the cavity.
    • Intramural fibroids > 5cm
  • Submucosal fibroids are best removed hysteroscopically (Esp type 0 and type 1)

 

Ref: Page 376, DC Duttas’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Endometrial Biopsy

questions.text: A 45-year lady presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for 3 months. On examination, she does not appear to be pale. Her BP is 150/90mmHg. An abdominal and pelvic exam is normal. A transvaginal scan shows a 2 cm Intramural fibroid and an endometrial thickness of 15mm. both the ovaries appear normal  What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endometrial Biopsy

Explanation:

  • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy.
  • It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age.
  • A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause. 
  • Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

Educational Objective:

  • Fibroids and endometrial hyperplasia/ malignancy usually coexist as both are hyperestrogenic states
  • Women in the peri-menopausal age group with fibroids with heavy menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

 

Ref: Page no 946, William’s Gynecology 3rd  edition

choices.text: B/l tubal block

questions.text: What is your interpretation of the following hysterosalpingogram?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Submucosal fibroid

 

Explanation:

 

  • This HSG shows a large well defined lesion in the uterus.
  • This is most likely a submucosal fibroid

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Normal: A normal HSG would show a regular, symmetrically shaped uterine cavity without any filling defects or irregularities. The fallopian tubes would be visible, with the contrast material flowing freely through them, indicating patency . No obstructions or unusual shapes should be present.

 

Option B. Asherman syndrome: This condition is characterized by the presence of intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue. On an HSG, Asherman syndrome may present as irregular filling defects within the uterine cavity or as a generally diminished size of the uterine cavity, depending on the severity of the adhesions.

 

Option C. Bilateral tubal block (B/l tubal block): In cases of bilateral tubal blockage, an HSG would show a lack of contrast material passing through one or both fallopian tubes ie. absence of free spill.

 

Option D. Submucosal fibroid: They are fibroids that grow just beneath the lining of the uterine cavity. On an HSG, these would appear as filling defects within the uterine cavity. They might show as smooth, round, or lobulated contours projecting into the cavity, disrupting the otherwise smooth and regular shape of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective: HSG is a valuable diagnostic tool in assessing the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes, which are crucial in evaluating female fertility. On an HSG, submucosal fibroids  would appear as filling defects within the uterine cavity.

 

Ref: Page 440, Williams Gynecology 3rd editionQuestion ID:19156

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard technique for tubal evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic evaluation

 

Explanation:

 

The following are tests done for tubal patency

 

  1. HSG (usually a preliminary test)
  2. Laparoscopic Chromotubation (Gold standard)
  3. Saline salpingography (better for intra uterine lesions)
  4. Others
    1. HyCoSy
    2. Falloposcopy

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography (HSG): This is a radiographic technique where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity, and X-ray images are taken to visualize the uterus and fallopian tubes. HSG is primarily used for evaluating the internal shape of the uterus and the patency of the fallopian tubes. While it's a commonly used first-line investigation for tubal assessment in infertility evaluations, it provides limited information about the external contour of the tubes and surrounding structures.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic chrompertubation: Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for tubal evaluation. It's a minimally invasive surgical procedure that provides a direct view of the pelvic organs, including the fallopian tubes. Laparoscopy not only allows for the assessment of tubal patency (often combined with chromopertubation, where a dye is passed through the tubes) but also enables visualization of the outer aspects of the tubes and the detection of other pelvic pathologies like endometriosis, adhesions, or fibroids that might affect tubal function. Its main limitation is that it's an invasive procedure requiring anesthesia.

 

Option C. Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS): SIS involves the infusion of saline into the uterine cavity during ultrasound examination. This technique  can be used to asses tubal patency,  it also enhances the visualization of the uterine cavity and can be useful in detecting abnormalities like polyps or fibroids.

 

Option D. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic organs, including the uterus and fallopian tubes, without using ionizing radiation. It's particularly useful in assessing uterine anomalies and some types of fibroids. However, MRI is less commonly used for direct assessment of tubal patency or minor tubal abnormalities compared to laparoscopy or HSG.

 

Educational Objective: Laparoscopic evaluation, as the gold standard, offers the most comprehensive assessment of the fallopian tubes and surrounding pelvic anatomy. However, other less invasive techniques like HSG and SIS also play important roles in initial assessments, especially in infertility workups. MRI, while offering excellent soft tissue contrast, is less specific for tubal patency

 

Page 441, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Low semen volume

questions.text: In treating hypertension, with beta blockers, which of the following semen parameter abnormalities may be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low semen volume

 

Explanation:

 

  • Low semen volume often simply reflects incomplete specimen collection or short abstinence interval.
  • However, it may indicate partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation.
    • Partial or complete vas deferens obstruction may be caused by infection, tumor, prior testicular or inguinal surgery, or trauma.
    • Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with
      • Diabetes mellitus
      • Spinal cord damage
      • Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves
      • Medications (β-blockers)

 

A postejaculatory urinalysis can detect sperm in the bladder and confirm the diagnosis. If urine is properly alkalinized, these sperm are viable and can be retrieved to achieve pregnancy

 

Let us explore the options given:

 

Option A. Azoospermia: This refers to the complete absence of sperm in the semen. While certain medications and health conditions can lead to azoospermia, beta-blockers are not typically associated with this severe a level of spermatogenic failure.

 

Option B. Oligospermia: Oligospermia means a lower than normal sperm count. Some medications and health issues can lead to oligospermia, but beta-blockers are not commonly linked to significant decreases in sperm count.

 

Option C. Teratospermia: Teratospermia is characterized by a high percentage of abnormally shaped sperm in the semen. This condition can be caused by various factors, including genetic defects, lifestyle choices, and exposure to certain chemicals or radiation. Beta-blockers are not known to specifically cause teratospermia.

 

Option D. Low semen volume (Correct Answer): Beta-blockers can lead to a decrease in semen volume. This effect is thought to be related to the general inhibitory effects of beta-blockers on the sympathetic nervous system, which plays a role in seminal emission. As a result, men taking beta-blockers may experience a reduction in the volume of ejaculate.

 

Educational Objective: While beta-blockers are effective in treating hypertension and various cardiovascular conditions, they can have side effects on sexual and reproductive health, such as reduced semen volume. It's important for healthcare providers to be aware of these potential side effects and discuss them with patients who are on long-term beta-blocker therapy, especially those who are concerned about fertility.

 

Ref: Page 443, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Asthenospermia refers to which of the following semen abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sperm motility

 

Explanation:

 

 

Let's go through each option:

 

Option A. Sperm Count: This refers to the concentration of sperm in a given volume of ejaculate. When the sperm count is lower than normal, it is termed oligospermia. Asthenospermia is not related to the count or concentration of sperm.

 

Option B. Semen Volume: This is the total volume of the ejaculated fluid. A low semen volume can be due to various causes, including hormonal imbalances or blockages in the reproductive tract. However, asthenospermia does not pertain to the volume of semen.

 

Option C. Sperm Motility (Correct Answer): Asthenospermia is specifically related to sperm motility, which refers to the ability of sperm to move efficiently. This is an important factor in fertility since sperm must be able to swim through the female reproductive tract to reach and fertilize the egg. Asthenospermia is characterized by a decreased percentage of motile sperm in the semen.

 

Option D. Sperm Morphology: This refers to the size and shape of sperm. Abnormalities in sperm morphology (teratospermia) can impact the ability of sperm to fertilize an egg. Asthenospermia, however, is specifically about the movement ability of sperm, not their shape or size.

 

Educational Objective: The key educational objective is to understand the different parameters evaluated in a semen analysis and their significance in assessing male fertility. Asthenospermia, a condition marked by reduced sperm motility, is an important factor to consider in the evaluation of male infertility. Recognizing the distinctions between sperm count, motility, volume, and morphology is crucial for healthcare providers in diagnosing and managing fertility issues in men. This knowledge is particularly relevant in the fields of urology, reproductive endocrinology, and andrology.

 

Ref: Page 443, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Zona penetration assay
DNA fragmentation index
Hypoosmotic swelling test
Mannose fluorescence assay

questions.text: Which of the following tests can differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoosmotic swelling test

 

  • Decreased sperm motility is termed asthenospermia.
  • Motility can be classified as
    • Rapid (grade 3 to 4)
    • Slow (grade 2)
    • Nonprogressive (grade 0 to 1) movement.
  • Total progressive motility is the percentage of sperm exhibiting forward movement (grades 2 to 4).
  • Causes of Asthenospermia: Prolonged abstinence, Antisperm antibodies, genital tract infections and varicocele.
  • To differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm, a hypoosmotic swelling test can be performed. Unlike dead sperm, living sperm can maintain an osmotic gradient. Thus, when mixed with a hypoosmotic solution, living, nonmotile sperm with normal membrane function swell and coil as fluid is absorbed. Once identified, these viable sperm may be used for intracytoplasmic sperm injection.

 

Let us look at the other options:

 

Option A. DNA Fragmentation test measures the amount of damaged DNA in sperm. Sperm DNA fragmentation (SDF) can be caused by extrinsic factors (i.e., heat exposure, smoking, environmental pollutants, and chemotherapeutics) as well as intrinsic factors (i.e., defective germ cell maturation, abortive apoptosis, and oxidative stress)

 

Option C.  The sperm penetration assay, or zona-free hamster oocyte penetration assay is utilized to measure the ability of sperm to undergo capacitation, fuse with the egg membrane and decondense the sperm head within the cytoplasm of the oocyte resulting in the formation of the male pronucleus. The test is scored by calculation the percentage of ova that are penetrated or the average number of sperm penetrations per ovum. It's used to evaluate the fertilizing capability of sperm but does not differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm.

 

Option D. Mannose Fluorescence Assay is used to assess the binding of sperm to mannose, a component of the egg's outer covering. It evaluates a specific aspect of sperm function related to fertilization but does not differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm.

 

Educational Objective: The hypoosmotic swelling test for assessing sperm viability, helps to differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm.

 

Ref: Page no 444, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition
